questions.text: Which of the following studies shown in the image below is performed for peptic ulcers?
questions.solution:
Peptic ulcers can be visualized using barium meal study. This investigation is depicted in image 2- showing contrast medium filling the stomach and duodenum.

Barium meal study is employed in conditions like gastric and peptic ulcers and gastric outlet obstruction.

Other options:

Image one shows a normal barium enema study. It is used in conditions like acute colitis, colonic fistula, colorectal cancer, ileocaecal tuberculosis, ulcerative colitis and ileocolic intussusception.

 

Image 3 is a barium swallow study in a case of eosinophilic esophagitis used to visualize the esophagus. It is used for the diagnosis of conditions like achalasia cardia, diffuse esophageal spasm, hiatus hernia, Zenker's diverticulum, esophageal webs, eosinophilic esophagitis, etc.

 

Image 4 shows a normal barium meal follow-through study which is performed for conditions like strictures, diverticula, masses and small bowel obstructions.

Related Pearl: Barium Studies

Barium swallow: Used to assess the pharynx, esophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used)

The image below is a barium swallow showing eosinophilic esophagitis and associated stricture:

Barium meal: Used to assess stomach and duodenum. (95% BaSO4 is used)

Barium meal followthrough: Used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used)

Barium enema: Used to assess the large intestine (25% BaSO4 is used)

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the condition shown below?

choices.text: Bilateral in more than 50% of the cases
Affects males more often than females

questions.solution:
The given intravenous urography (IVU) image depicts cobra head/adder head deformity which is a classic sign of ureterocele. It is associated with dysplastic renal tissue.

Ureterocele:

A ureterocele is the cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter. It is thought to be caused due to ureteric orifice atresia. It is observed more in females than males in a 4:1 preponderance and is bilateral in about 10% of the cases. They are similar to ectopic ureters wherein the upper pole of the kidney is drained. This condition is typically associated with dysplastic and non-functional renal tissue.

Clinical presentation:

  • Children with ureterocele usually present with infection.
  • Adults present with renal stones.

Diagnosis:

  • IVU shows a classical cobra head sign but is relatively infrequently performed these days.
  • Cystoscopy shows a bulging, translucent swelling involving the ureteric orifice where there is urinary stasis. It is emptied by ureteric peristalsis.

Treatment:

  • Surgical excision with re-implantation of the ureter is the treatment of choice for simple ureterocele.
  • Renal stones associated with ureterocele are removed using an endoscopic incision
  • An advanced disease that causes hydronephrosis or pyonephrosis is an indication for nephrectomy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presents with abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. Examination reveals mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant and icterus. She adopted a stray dog a few months back. CT scan revealed the following image. A skin test and ELISA are performed to confirm the diagnosis. What type of hypersensitivity reaction is the skin test that is performed based on?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing icterus and right upper quadrant pain, a history of recently adopting a street dog, and CT showing a cyst in the left liver with a typical multivesicular image is highly suggestive of a hydatid cyst. It is confirmed by Casoni’s intradermal test which is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.

Casoni intradermal test: It involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilized fluid from hydatid cysts/human cysts on the forearm. An equal volume of saline is injected into the other forearm as a control. It is observed for the next 30 minutes and again after 1-2 days. The fluid used for the test is sterilized by Seitz filtration. A wheal response at the injection site occurring within 20 minutes is considered positive. It is followed by a secondary reaction 8 hours later.

Hydatid Cysts:

Dogs are the definitive hosts of Echinococcus granulosus. Sheep are the usual intermediate hosts, but humans are accidental intermediate hosts. Humans are end-stage hosts of the parasite since there is no human-to-human transmission.

Primary hydatid cysts most commonly occur in the liver. The next most common site is the lung, specifically the lower lobe of the right lung. Most patients are asymptomatic but when symptomatic, the patient presents with hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice.

Investigations: 

Computed tomography (CT) scan is accurate for detecting hydatid cysts. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline and septae and demonstrates daughter cysts and extra-hepatic cysts. Sometimes, when there is disruption of the inner layers, it can present as/with:

  • Air–fluid level with a floating membrane - water lily sign/ camalote sign 
  • A double-wall, dry cyst with crumpled membranes lying at its bottom - Rising sun sign/ Serpent sign
  • When all the contents are removed - empty cyst sign

Serology: Detection of serum antibodies against 8 and 16 kDa antigens using indirect hemagglutination (IHA), indirect immunofluorescence, ELISA, and slide latex agglutination test can be used to support the clinical diagnosis.

Treatment :

  • Early stages of the disease can be treated with puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR). Albendazole 4 days before the procedure, continued till 4 weeks afterward.
  • Surgery is the treatment of choice when PAIR is not possible. The preferred surgical approach is pericystectomy. Since recurrence is common, pre and postoperative chemotherapy with albendazole for 2 years is recommended.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with cough and shortness of breath. He does not complain of fever. There is occasional sputum production on coughing. He has been smoking about one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 35 years. Physical examination shows crepitations in bilateral lung fields. His chest X-Ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing a chronic smoker with cough and dyspnea and chest x-ray showing signs of overinflation are suggestive of severe diffuse emphysema.

Emphysema is is a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease that is characterized by irreversible enlargement of the airspaces distal to the terminal bronchiole, accompanied by destruction of their walls.

Patients with emphysema were often described as pink puffers, as they are thin, non-cyanotic at rest, and prominently use the accessory muscles of respiration. On examination, the patient is barrel-chested and dyspneic, with prolonged expiration. The patient may sit forward in a tripod position.

Radiological signs of overinflation are the best predictors of the presence and severity of emphysema. They include:

  • Height of the right - >29.9 cm,
  • Location of the right hemidiaphragm at or below the anterior aspect of the seventh rib
  • Flattening of the hemidiaphragm
  • Enlargement of the retrosternal space (seen in lateral CXR)
  • Widening of the sterno-diaphragmatic angle (seen in lateral CXR)
  • Narrowing of the transverse cardiac diameter.

Other options:

Option B - Acute respiratory distress syndrome is clinically characterized by dyspnea and tachypnea which is usually followed by increasing respiratory failure, hypoxemia, and cyanosis unless medically intervened. Radiography shows the presence of diffuse bilateral infiltrates which is as shown below.

Option C - Atypical pneumonia is caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae, and Legionella species as well as respiratory viruses such as influenza viruses, adenoviruses, human metapneumovirus, and respiratory syncytial viruses. These do not grow easily on standard cultures.

They present with slightly different symptoms than typical pneumonia such as headache, myalgia, a low-grade fever, and a dry cough.  Chest x-ray shows patchy inflammatory changes, often confined to the pulmonary interstitium and fails to show any consolidation.

Option D - Pneumothorax refers to the presence of gas (air) in the pleural space. When this collection of gas is constantly enlarging, there is resulting compression of mediastinal structures.

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Visible visceral pleural edge is seen as a very thin, sharp white line
  • No lung markings are seen peripheral to this line
  • The peripheral space is radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung.
  • The lung may completely collapse.
  • The mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless a tension pneumothorax is present.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may also be present.
  • Deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph where the costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign.

questions.text: You are working as a junior resident in the ENT department when a patient brings the following X-Ray image. Which of the following structures is best visualized in this view?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a radiographic image captured in the occipitofrontal view or Caldwell view. This is the best view for visualizing the frontal sinus.

Caldwell's view is taken with the nose and forehead are touching the x-ray film. The X-ray beam is projected caudally at a 15-20 degree angle.

Structures seen in Caldwell's view are:

  • Frontal sinuses (seen best)
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

The image below shows the projection of the x-ray beams in relation to the position of the head.

The image below shows the sinuses seen in Caldwell view :

 

The best view for visualizing the maxillary sinus is Waters' view. It is taken in such a way that nose and chin of the patient touch the film while an X-ray beam is projected from behind. Waters’ view with an open mouth is preferred as it also shows sphenoid sinus.

The submentovertical (basal) view is best suited for visualizing the sphenoid sinus. It is taken when the vertex near the X-ray film and the X-ray beam is projected at right angles to the film from the submental area. The sphenoid, posterior ethmoid, and maxillary sinuses are seen best in that order.

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of temporal bone

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the casualty following a fall on an outstretched hand. He complains of pain in his left elbow. Examination reveals tenderness and swelling over his left elbow. An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true with respect to this condition?

choices.text: Vascular injury commonly involves the brachial artery
Ulnar nerve  is most commonly injured in the extension-type
Almost all injuries are of the flexion-type
Cubitus valgus is the most common angular deformity

questions.solution:
The clinical features and x-ray showing posterior fat pad sign are suggestive of supracondylar fracture of the humerus where vascular injury commonly involves the brachial artery.

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

It is most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years. The extension type is seen in 98% of the cases while the rest are flexion type. The mechanism of injury involved is usually a fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension. Gartland classification is used for the classification of supracondylar fractures and is of four types.

On examination:

There may be an S-shaped deformity at the elbow. If the proximal fracture fragment is sharp and has penetrated the muscles and fascia, a dimple may be seen on the skin above the elbow (dimple sign). The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture.

Radiology:  

  • An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by hematoma.
  • Baumann’s angle is the angle between the horizontal line of the elbow and the line drawn through the lateral epiphysis and long axis of the arm. It is normally less than 5 degrees and is checked with the other arm.

The most common nerve to be injured in extension type is the anterior interosseous nerve while the ulnar nerve is injured in flexion type. The brachial artery is most likely involved when there are blood vessel involvement.

Cubitus Varus deformity:

Cubitus varus or gunstock deformity is the most common angular deformity that results from supracondylar fractures in children. The static deformities of cubitus varus with respect to the distal fragment are :

  • Posterior displacement
  • Horizontal rotation
  • Coronal tilt.

Treatment: 

Conservative management is attempted with closed reduction using traction and counter-traction. Successful reduction is when the long axis of arm and forearm lie in parallel. If conservative management fails, skin or skeletal traction is employed but is not used anymore due to better modalities of treatment.

Surgery is by either closed reduction and percutaneous internal fixation with K-wires or open reduction and internal fixation with wires or plates

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the condition shown in the image below?

choices.text: Malunion can happen if this condition is not treated
The patient may be able to walk
Avascular necrosis is the most common complication
Shortening of limb is less than 1 inch

questions.solution:
The radiograph shows a fracture neck of the femur. Non-union is a complication of this fracture, not malunion. 

Malunion is a complication of inter-trochanteric fractures.

Complications of fracture neck of the femur are:

  • Avascular necrosis (most common)
  • Non-union
  • Osteonecrosis of the femoral head may lead to secondary osteoarthritis after many years

Option B: In impacted fracture neck of femur, the patient may be able to walk.

Option D: Shortening of the limb is less than 1 inch in fracture neck of femur.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presenting with halitosis and regurgitation, underwent a barium swallow scan as shown below. Weakness located in which of the following muscles predisposes to the suspected condition​?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of a patient with halitosis and regurgitation with the GIF of an X-ray showing the barium swallow filling a sac in the posterior pharyngeal wall is highly suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. It protrudes through the Killian's dehiscence, a potential space present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts: The upper thyropharyngeus and the lower cricopharyngeus. The cricopharyngeus muscle is divisible into the superficial oblique component (pars oblique) and the deeper transverse component (pars fundiformis). These 2 components of the muscle have a potential space between them termed Killian's dehiscence.  

As a result of the uncoordinated contraction between the cricopharyngeus and upper oesophagal sphincter, mucosal herniation through the Killian's dehiscence gives rise to Zenker's diverticulum. This diverticulum is a common site for food impaction and accumulation (halitosis, regurgitation) and may cause dysphagia in affected patients. 

Note - Another potential site of diverticulum formation is the Laimer's triangle, situated below the cricopharyngeus and above the longitudinal fibres of the oesophagus. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: An infant delivered at full-term by normal vaginal delivery, presented with respiratory distress immediately after birth. Chest X-ray showed the following picture. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray chest shows intra-thoracic bowel shadows along with mediastinal shift suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

The common clinical presentation is as follows:

  • Respiratory distress
  • Dextrocardia
  • Scaphoid abdomen

Prenatal diagnosis is done by ultrasonography. Lung-to-head ratio (LHR) is used to assess severity in patients with left-sided CDH. An LHR value of <1 is associated with a very poor prognosis, whereas an LHR >1.4 predicts a more favourable outcome.

Option A: Hyaline membrane disease is a syndrome in premature infants caused by developmental insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant production and structural immaturity in the lungs.

Option B: Meconium aspiration syndrome is the aspiration of meconium-stained amniotic fluid, which can occur before, during or immediately after birth. Meconium is the first intestinal discharge from newborns, a viscous, dark-green substance composed of intestinal epithelial cells, lanugo, mucus, and intestinal secretions.

Option D: During normal delivery, the compression of the rib cage while passing through the mother's vaginal canal helps to remove fluid from the lungs. However, newborns who are delivered via cesarean birth may have excess fluid in the lungs and therefore be hypoxic and develop transient tachypnea.

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

  • Mediastinal shift
  • Bowel loops in the left hemithorax

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Low lung volume
  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

 Meconium Aspiration Syndrome

  • Hyperinflation
  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: You are asked to opine on the age of an adolescent boy allegedly involved in a crime. He claims to be a juvenile and pleads for a trial in the juvenile court. Based on the X-ray shown below, the likely age of the boy is:
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the appearance of pisiform but no fusion of base of 1st metacarpal. Therefore, the age is more than 10 years and less than 17 years. Among the given options, the age of the boy is likely to be <17 years.

The base of all metacarpals appears at 2-3 years of age and fuses at 15 -17 years of age. Since it is not fused in this case, the age is less than 17 years. If it has fused the likely age is more than 15 years.

Pisiform ossification center appears at 10-12 years of age (options C and D). Since it is present in this case, the age of the child is more than 10 years. If it had not appeared, the likely age is <12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18-19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5-6 years of age and fuses at 17-18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be less than 18.

Related Pearl: Appearance of ossification centres of carpal bones

  • Capitate – 2 months (1-3 months)
  • Hamate – 3 months (2-4 months)
  • Triquetrum – 3 years
  • Lunate, Scaphoid, trapezoid, Trapezium – 4 years in females and 5 years in males
  • Pisiform – 9 or 10 years in females and 12 years in males

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient was brought to the emergency department with complaints of severe headache, vomiting, and progressive weakness of the right upper and lower limb weakness. A CT image of the patient is shown. Which of the following drugs is best suited to reduce morbidity in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the patient presenting with complaints of headache, vomiting, and paralysis and the CT image showing blood in the cistern is suggestive of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) where nimodipine is best suited to reduce morbidity.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage is the hemorrhage in the subarachnoid space between the arachnoid and pia mater, mixed with CSF.

After head trauma, it is mostly caused as a result of the rupture of a saccular aneurysm. Other causes include bleeding from a vascular malformation such as arteriovenous malformation or dural arteriovenous fistula and an intracerebral hemorrhage extending into the subarachnoid space.

Some SAHs may be limited to the perimesencephalic cisterns and is arterial in origin but there could be a venous or capillary source. Manifesting features are due to raised intracranial pressure.

Nimodipine is indicated to relieve a neurological deficit occurring secondary to cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid haemorrhage. It is a member of the dihydropyridine group of calcium channel blockers and causes vasodilation in cerebral blood vessels. It is lipid-soluble and has a high affinity for cerebral blood vessels and appears to reduce morbidity after subarachnoid haemorrhage.

questions.text: The plain x-ray shows a particular change in ribs. This is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The x-ray depicts the inferior rib notching, which is a finding associated with coarctation of the aorta.

Coarctation of the aorta is the narrowing/constriction of the aorta most commonly occurring at origin of ductus arteriosis. It can also be seen preductal or post ductal and is associated with Turner syndrome.

Preductal or infantile type has severe coarctation become symptomatic as soon as the duct begins to close. Differential cyanosis and radial-femoral delay are classic signs.

Adult or juxta ductal is usually mild and goes unnoticed until adolescence. They present as weakness, pain or claudication in legs after exercise, hypertension in the upper extremities with weak pulses and hypotension in the lower extremities.

Roesler sign-Notching of the inferior margin of the ribs(4th-8th) from pressure erosion by enlarged collateral vessels is common by late childhood. 

A figure of 3 sign (Reverse 3) is a contour abnormality of the aorta as shown below.

Rib notching refers to the deformation of the superior or inferior surface of the rib. Osteogenesis imperfecta, rheumatoid arthritis and hyperparathyroidism are associated with superior rib notching.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic. She gives a history of 3 spontaneous first-trimester abortions. Routine investigations were done along with hysterosalpingography and MR imaging of the uterus which revealed the following images. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing recurrent first-trimester pregnancy losses and hysterosalpingography and MRI images are suggestive of a septate uterus.

A septate uterus is one where the uterus has a normal outline with the presence of an internal indentation at the fundal midline exceeding 50% of the uterine wall thickness. 

Obstetric outcomes in Septate uterus:

  • Spontaneous abortion
  • Preterm delivery
  • Repeated pregnancy loss
  • Intrauterine growth restriction
  • Abnormal presentations

Imaging modalities used for diagnosis:

Combined hysteroscopy and laparoscopy help to differentiate between a bicornuate uterus and a septate uterus. A septate uterus can be identified with the presence of a uterine fundus.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) cannot reliably differentiate between a septate and a bicornuate/arcuate uterus. If the angle of divergence between the two uterine cavities is <75°, the defect will most likely be a septate uterus. If the divergence angle is >75° but <105° a diagnosis cannot be made.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is an accurate and noninvasive investigation to make a diagnosis of a septate uterus. If the septum extends to >30% of the septal cavity, surgical resection is indicated.

Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome. The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies.

Other options: 

Option A: Bicorporeal uterus is a uterus where the outline of the fundus is abnormal. An indentation that exceeds 50% of the wall thickness of the uterus at the fundal midline is indicative of a bicorporeal uterus.

Option B: Dysmorphic uterus is one where the fundal outline of the uterus is preserved but the presence of an abnormal uterine cavity excluding a septum.

Option C: A Hemi-uterus is one that is unilaterally formed due to development on only one side. The other side of the uterus is either incomplete or absent. The uterus that is present is fully functional. 

The following image shows the anomalies mentioned with a diagrammatic representation:

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text:
Match the following USG images with the conditions they are seen in.
  1. Unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy
  2. Monochorionic diamniotic gestation
  3. Dichorionic diamniotic gestation
  4. Spina bifida
questions.solution:
The option matching the USG images with the associated condition is 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B.

Image 1 shows the lambda sign (also known as the twin peak sign) in ultrasonography, seen in dichorionic diamniotic gestation. Its presence is highly suggestive of dichorionicity.

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

The image given below shows the lambda/twin peak.


Image 2 shows the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II malformation.


Image 3 shows the bagel sign which is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

This sign has a positive predictive value of 95% in ectopic pregnancy. A normal corpus luteum can also mimic this sign but can be differentiated by a bimanual pelvic examination.

The image given below shows the bagel sign.


Image 4 shows the T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation. It is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

The image given below shows a T sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with dyspnea on exertion and bluish discoloration of lips, which is relieved on squatting. A chest x-ray is taken and is shown below. Which of the following is the primary defect responsible for this condition?

choices.text: Anterior deviation of the infundibular septum
Pulmonary venous connection to the SVC
Ostium secundum defect in the fossa ovalis

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing cyanotic spells and chest x-ray showing a boot-shaped cardiac silhouette are suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The primary defect is an anterior deviation of the infundibular septum (the muscular septum that separates the aortic and pulmonary outflows).

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a cyanotic congenital heart condition and has been classically characterized by the following components:

  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)
  • Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta), and
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

Paroxysmal hypercyanotic attacks (hypoxic, “blue,” or “tet” spells) are a problem during the 1st year of life and may last from a few minutes to a few hours. The child can have shortness of breath and bluish discoloration of lips which is relieved on squatting. Short episodes are followed by generalized weakness and sleep. Severe spells may progress to unconsciousness and occasionally to convulsions or hemiparesis.

Older children with tetralogy of Fallot characteristically increase pulmonary blood flow by squatting. Squatting is a compensatory mechanism, it increases peripheral vascular resistance (PVR) and thus decreases the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt across the ventricular septal defect (VSD).

Chest X-ray describes "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

  • "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot.
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

Other options:

Option B - A pulmonary venous connection to the superior vena cava (SVC) is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). It is a cyanotic congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary veins drain directly into the right atrium, coronary sinus, SVC, IVC, or ductus venosus.

On chest x-ray, supracardiac TAPVR presents with the snowman appearance of the heart which is as shown below

Option C - A downward displacement of an abnormal tricuspid valve is seen in Ebstein anomaly, a cyanotic heart disease. Infants with severe disease present with marked cyanosis, massive cardiomegaly, and long holosystolic murmurs. Death may result from cardiac failure, hypoxemia, and pulmonary hypoplasia. 

Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly caused by enlargement of the right atrium giving rise to a massive box-shaped cardiac shadow as shown below.

Option D - An ostium secondum defect in the fossa ovalis is the most common site of atrial septal defects (ASD). ASDs are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum causing a left-to-right shunt.

Most ASDs are asymptomatic and are picked up during routine physical examinations. A widely fixed and split S2 is characteristic. A soft ejection systolic murmur best heard over the left upper sternal border is also commonly found. A mild left precordial bulge and a right ventricular systolic lift may be palpable at the left sternal border. Sometimes, a pulmonic ejection click can be heard.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: A patient with a severe, treatment-resistant neuropsychiatric condition is referred to the neurosurgery OPD. The surgeon proposes a burr-hole procedure where the given sites are destroyed via thermocoagulation. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to be suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of anterior cingulotomy (ACING), which is a neurosurgical treatment for obsessive-compulsive disorder. Anterior cingulotomy involves creating bilateral lesions in the anterior cingulate cortex under stereotactic guidance. 

Subcaudate tractotomy (capsulotomy) can also be used in the management of treatment-unresponsive OCD.

Prefrontal lobotomy was introduced by Egas Moniz as a method of psychosurgery for treatment-resistant mental disorders, particularly major depressive disorder and OCD.

Other indications for psychosurgery include:

  • Chronic and incapacitating schizophrenia with severe depression not responding to all modes of treatment.
  • Chronic and incapacitating anxiety disorder not responding to all modes of treatment.

questions.text: The given CT finding is associated with which of the following genodermal disorders?
questions.solution:
The CT brain shows tram-track cortical calcifications, a characteristic feature of Sturge-Weber syndrome.

It occurs due to leptomeningeal hemangioma, resulting in a vascular steal affecting the subjacent cortex and white matter producing localized ischemia and calcification.

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: A patient with chronic gout now presented to the emergency room after sustaining trauma to his left foot. Identify the abnormality in his X-ray given below.
questions.solution:
The given X-ray of a patient with chronic gout shows Martel's sign.

Martel's sign also known as the G sign, or rat-bite erosion, refers to the punched-out lytic lesion and overhanging margin of the new bone along the edge of erosion seen in chronic tophaceous gout.

Option A: Podagra is the inflammation of the base of the great toe (metatarsophalangeal joint) during flares of gout. It is not a radiological sign.

Option C: Chopart's fracture is a fracture between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints.

Option D: March fracture is fracture neck of 2nd or 3rd metatarsal.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient presented with pain in the right knee region for the past three months. On examination, the right knee region is swollen and there is a reduced range of motion. An x-ray taken for further evaluation reveals the following. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the x-ray showing an expansile, eccentric, sub-articular soap bubble appearance is suggestive of Giant cell tumor (GCT) or Osteoclastoma.

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults of age 20 to 40 years with slight female predominance. It is seen exclusively in adults and affects the epiphysis of long bones, commonly in the distal end of the femur followed by the proximal tibia. Common presenting complaints are swelling and vague pain. Sometimes, the patient presents for the first time with a pathological fracture through the lesion.

  • Important x-ray features of a GCT
    • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis.
    • Eccentric location, most often subchondral.
    • Expansion of the overlying cortex.
    • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance.
    • No calcification within the tumor.
    • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

Histologically, GCTs consist of undifferentiated spindle cells profusely interspersed with multi-nucleated giant cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue. The image below shows the histopathology of osteoclastoma.

The treatment of choice for GCT is extended curettage and bone grafting.

  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like distal ulna, clavicle, and proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.

Other options:

Option A: Aneurysmal bone cyst is a benign, expansile lytic lesion of the metaphysis of the long bones, comprised of blood-filled cystic spaces. It is more common in the age group of 5-20 years. These occur more commonly in the metaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, and humerus. Patients usually present with pain and swelling. The x-ray image is given below:

 

Option B: Osteochondromas are benign bone tumors that present commonly in the adolescent age group. Radiograph and MRI would reveal pedunculated bony protuberance with a stalk with a growing cartilaginous cap (as shown below) or some lesions with a broad sessile base.

 

Option D: Osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites. The periosteal reaction is the typical finding and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance (as shown below) on the X-ray.

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV patient presents with a productive cough with blood-stained sputum, evening rise of temperature, and weight loss for 3 weeks. His chest x-ray image is shown below.  What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an evening rise of temperature and productive cough for more than 2 weeks in an HIV patient and a chest x-ray image showing bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and cavity in the left apical region is highly suggestive of reactivation pulmonary tuberculosis (TB).

Pulmonary TB is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Pulmonary TB due to exogenous (new infection) or endogenous (reactivation of a dormant primary lesion) infection in a sensitized individual is called post-primary or reactivation or secondary or adult-type TB.

The apical and posterior segments of the upper lobe and superior segments of the lower lobe are most commonly involved in post-primary TB due to increased ventilation in these segments than in the lower zones.

Patients often present with fever, productive cough, blood-streaked sputum, night sweats, malaise, loss of appetite, and weight loss.

Investigations: 

  1. Sputum microscopy:
    • Ziehl-Neelsen staining - the presence of acid-fast bacilli
    • Auramine fluorescence staining
  2. Sputum culture:
    • Sold media (Lowenstein-Jensen medium) or liquid media (MGIT)
  3. Catridge-based nucleic acid amplification test (CB-NAAT) is currently the first-line preferred diagnostic test.
  4. Radiograph imaging - Chest x-ray and CT chest 

Radiological findings include ill-defined opacification in the upper lobes, consolidation, collapse, and cavitation.

  1. Typically, the disease is parenchymal without nodal enlargement.
  2. Cavitation is a distinguishing feature of post-primary TB;
    • Typical cavities are thick-walled and irregular.
    • Air-fluid levels are uncommon in TB. The presence of air-fluid levels indicates superadded infections.
  3. Upper-lobe involvement with cavitation and the absence of lymphadenopathy distinguishes post-primary TB from primary TB.

Complications of pulmonary TB:

  • Massive hemoptysis
  • Cor pulmonale
  • Fibrosis/emphysema
  • Pleural effusion
  • Lung/pleural calcification 
  • Aspergilloma/chronic aspergillosis
  • Obstructive airways disease
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Bronchopleural fistula

The image below shows chest x-ray findings of a post-primary TB with a cavity (black arrows) in the right upper lobe and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates (white triangles) in the apical regions.

Option A:

Aspergilloma or fungal ball is a late manifestation of chronic cavitary pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA) caused by Aspergillus species. A fungal ball is formed within the pulmonary cavity of CPA by the peeled-off inner layer of the cavity. 

Patients present with chronic features of fatigue, weight loss, cough, hemoptysis, and wheezing. However, clinical features such as foul-smelling sputum and night sweats are more commonly observed in TB, which helps in differentiating the two conditions.

Chest x-ray shows a spherical or ovoid mass within a cavity. The mass is mobile. CT demonstrates a rounded mass within a cavity. Monod sign refers to the air that surrounds an aspergilloma in a pre-existing pulmonary cavity.

Images below show Chest x-ray and CT findings in aspergilloma.

Option C:

Loculated pleural effusion:

A pleural effusion is the excessive accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. Loculated effusions occur most commonly in association with conditions that cause intense pleural inflammation, such as empyema, hemothorax, and tuberculosis. Fissural loculations mimic tumor tissue and are most commonly seen in congestive heart failure.

Patients present with typical pleuritic chest pain that increases on deep inspiration, coughing, sneezing, dyspnea, and a dry cough. Physical signs of loculated pleural effusion include reduced tactile fremitus, dullness on percussion, and diminished or absent breath sounds. Shifting dullness is absent in loculated effusions.

Chest x-ray shows blunting of the costophrenic and cardiophrenic angles. It also shows a homogenous opacity, which could be lateral or lamellar, mediastinal, apical, subpulmonic, or fissural (biconvex opacities). Loculated effusions are confirmed by lateral decubitus x-ray or USG.

The chest x-ray below shows a left-sided lamellar loculated pleural effusion.

Option D:

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) is caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii that is an opportunistic pathogen that is an important cause of pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts, particularly those with HIV infection, and follows a human-to-human transmission.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever, dyspnea, and cough that is usually non-productive. It ultimately results in respiratory distress and death.

Chest x-ray imaging shows a normal film if the disease is suspected early or diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar and symmetric. High-resolution CT shows ground-glass opacities.

X-ray images of two patients with PCP are given below.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB
